messages.subject: Re: NAMBAN TETSU
messages.msgSnippet: It is surely important that we define what exactly we mean by namban tetsu .  Since the word namban , as adopted by the Japanese during the Heian period, was
messages.messageBody:
It is surely important that we define what exactly we mean by 'namban
tetsu'. Since the word 'namban', as adopted by the Japanese during
the Heian period, was applied to all foreigners, irrespective of
their origin, the term 'namban iron' should surely be applied to all
iron not having its origin in the smelting of native ore.

The importation of such iron into Japan from Korea is described in
writings of the early part of the third century AD, local production
occurring only a few centuries later than this. Namban iron thus
existed in Japan many centuries before the Dutch arrival there.

If, however, you consider - in my opinion, quite wrongly - that the
term 'namban iron' refers to that of a European source, the Dutch
started to import iron, with its origins in China, Korea and India,
in the early C17. Iron and steel were both imported by the Dutch and
the English during the C17.

Finally, in defining the term, does one include under the heading
locally produced iron that contains a proportion of the metal from
foreign sources? If so - as I believe one should - only iron produced
locally, exclusively from the smelting of local ore, can be excluded
from the label of 'namban iron'.

JPL.

messages.messageBody:
Hi all,

Well, I guess my memory is bad. I found a large number of 1st gen.
Yasutsugu works with Namban-tetsu o motte in the signatures. None are
dated, but some are given as circa Keicho. So, it seems to have been
available earlier than I thought.

Gordon

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: NAMBAN TETSU
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Barry, I will check through my sources when I get home later today. I do not recall ever seeing a first generation Yasutsugu with a Namban-tetsu
messages.messageBody:
Hi Barry,



I will check through my sources when I get home later today. I do not recall
ever seeing a first generation Yasutsugu with a Namban-tetsu inscription,
and if one exits, being dated will be extraordinary. On the other hand, my
memory may just be faulty. We can also go back to Oda Nobunaga for the
foreign dress thing. He is said to have had a Namban-gusoku and his
standard was a Portuguese hat. He also affected foreign wear. Nonetheless, I
still suspect that the importation of steel came after the Dutch were set up
in Dejima, the country was pacified and smiths were largely established in
large urban centers. That would put the use back past 1615 and the fall of
Osaka castle.



It is interesting that Yasutsugu should be negatively compared to Umetada
Myoju in terms of blade making. Myoju left scant numbers of swords and is
really not considered much of a sword-smith. Horikawa Kunihiro is largely
credited with starting the Shinto tradition due to the large number of
swords he produced and the size of his school, which included the founders
of the Osaka Shinto. Yasutsugu at his best is excellent, but he seems to
have produced a lot of so-so stuff.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Barry Thomas
Sent: Friday, February 23, 2007 9:50 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: NAMBAN TETSU



John alerted us to the nihonto.com Yasutsugu article, which stated:

> About this time, non oriental foreigners made
> their presence felt in Japan for the first time. Things from
> the "West" were new, exciting, strange, and highly sought after.

That may be true for namban tetsu, but for other things it is not true.
Hideyoshi died in September 1598 and I have seen a picture of Hideyoshi's
court adopting Portuguese-style dress. Also Western food was introduced to
Japan in the late 16th century:

> Batter-coated deep frying was introduced to the Japanese by Portuguese
missionaries during the 16th century.
(see wikipedia http://en.wikipedia <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tempura>
.org/wiki/Tempura)

It would be interesting to know Yasutsugu I's earliest dated sword with the
namban tetsu inscription. Any takers???

Regards,
Barry Thomas.

Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: NAMBAN TETSU

Hi, ThAround the 11th or 12th year of this same period of Keicho
(1606-1607), Yasutsugu's fame reached the point that he was called to
Edo (Tokyo) to share his time with Tokugawa Ieyasu. About this time
Yasutsugu was given the privilege of using the character "Yasu" from
Tokugawa Ieyasu's name. Thus he changed his name to Yasutsugu from
that point on. About the same time ( some feel it was a few years
later) he was given the additional privilege of carving the Hollyhock
crest ( Aoi mon) on his blades. These privileges were given in
perpetuity to Yasutsugu and his descendents. Thus the Yasutsugu
swordsmiths became the kaji of the Tokugawa Family.

Earlier I raised the question of what made Yasutsugu's fame and
fortune seem to spread disproportionately to his skill when we
compare him to some of his contemporary smiths such as Umetada Myoju
and Horikawa Kunihiro. About this time, non oriental foreigners made
their presence felt in Japan for the first time. Things from
the "West" were new, exciting, strange, and highly sought after.
Yasutsugu was one of the first advocates of using namban tetsu
(foreign steel) in his swords. He proudly incised this fact on the
nakago of his later works. It was new, it was exciting, and there is
no doubt that this use of foreign steel helped spread his fameis is
from an article on nihonto.com

messages.messageBody:
Hi, ThAround the 11th or 12th year of this same period of Keicho
(1606-1607), Yasutsugu's fame reached the point that he was called to
Edo (Tokyo) to share his time with Tokugawa Ieyasu. About this time
Yasutsugu was given the privilege of using the character "Yasu" from
Tokugawa Ieyasu's name. Thus he changed his name to Yasutsugu from
that point on. About the same time ( some feel it was a few years
later) he was given the additional privilege of carving the Hollyhock
crest ( Aoi mon) on his blades. These privileges were given in
perpetuity to Yasutsugu and his descendents. Thus the Yasutsugu
swordsmiths became the kaji of the Tokugawa Family.

Earlier I raised the question of what made Yasutsugu's fame and
fortune seem to spread disproportionately to his skill when we
compare him to some of his contemporary smiths such as Umetada Myoju
and Horikawa Kunihiro. About this time, non oriental foreigners made
their presence felt in Japan for the first time. Things from
the "West" were new, exciting, strange, and highly sought after.
Yasutsugu was one of the first advocates of using namban tetsu
(foreign steel) in his swords. He proudly incised this fact on the
nakago of his later works. It was new, it was exciting, and there is
no doubt that this use of foreign steel helped spread his fameis is
from an article on nihonto.com

Yasutsugu 1st inscribed 'Nanban tetsu wo motte' on some of his swords, according to the Meikan his dated blades range from 1613 to 1621
Alan

From: Gordon Robson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, February 22, 2007 12:53 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: NAMBAN TETSU


Hi all,

Although this is way out of my field, based on inscriptions that claim
namban-tetsu use, I would push its introduction way past the late 16th cent.
The swords with such inscriptions are by smiths working in large residential
areas like Edo and Osaka. They are mainly late 17th and 18th century smiths.
I would think that the Dutch simply saw a lucrative market for iron ore and
began to import it through Dejima. We have all probably seen the photos of
the tear-shaped ingots that were imported for this use.

Gordon

messages.msgSnippet: Hi Dr. Lissenden, John, I believe you are right on about the cannon being unlikely to be iron. Bronze cannon were so much easier to produce and less likely to
messages.messageBody:
Hi Dr. Lissenden, John, I believe you are right on about the cannon
being unlikely to be iron. Bronze cannon were so much easier to
produce and less likely to fail than iron. The only difference of
import at this time is bronze was more expensive to use. So, I went
to a forum where there are some dedicated historians. I paste the
answers below.


Anyway, this might answer your question. The book 'The Dutch
Discovery Of Japan' by Dirk Jan Barreveld (which is full of errors,
but still helpful in gaining an understanding of Dutch trade) states
that a report filed by a Jesuit sent to inspect the ship says that
the ship had '19 pieces of guns made of bronze' (other sources give
the number as 18 or 26).
From Turnbull's Osaka book-Ieyasu had 10 European cannon at the
battles of Osaka in 1614-15. 5 were Dutch made 'Ishibaya' cannons
(which fired shot ranging from 12 lbs to 35-40 lbs-it's unclear which
type Ieyasu had, though). These were likely from the cannon taken
from DeLiefde. The other 5 were bought from the English East India
Company and were invoiced by Richard Cocks on December 5, 1614. They
included 4 culverins (17.5 lbs) and one saker (5.5 lbs). Out of about
300 artillery pieces Ieyasu fielded at Osaka, these were the only
heavy siege guns apart from one Japanese gun. This was
the 'Shinbatsuji' gun, which was made by Shibatsuji Ryuemon Sukenobu.
It was about 11 feet long with a 90 mm bore, and fired shot about the
same size as small Dutch cannon. Unfortunately, it's not noted what
they're made of-the picture of the Japanese gun (which is at
Yasukuni) looks like it was bronze. My Japanese books would likely
have this info, but they're not here .

AND

Samurai William, p.91, states that the Liefde's cannon were bronze

I still await more information on possible early sources for
nambantetsu. I will let you know. It seems so far that article has a
lot of supposition. John

messages.messageBody:
Dear Barry

I was very interested by the article that you posted on namban tetsu,
but am a little unhappy about the implied supposition that cannon from
the 'De Liefde' were the original source of this metal.

I had believed that bronze - a mixture of 90% copper and 10% tin - was
the preferred metal used for the casting of cannon. Although cast-iron
cannon became available ca 1550, these were much more difficult to
cast, and bronze remained the metal of choice until the mid to late
C17. Since the 'De Liefde' arrived in Kyushu in 1600, is it not highly
likely that its cannon were of bronze rather than of iron?

Is there an expert on cannon out there somewhere who can clarify this
point for me?

Regards, John L.

All,

I've just discovered this little gem about the history of Namban tetsu (foreign steel) in Japanese history and the involvement of the Dutch V.O.C. Company. Namban tetsu was used in the making of swords and so recorded on the sword tang.

http://tokensugita.com/NT.htm

Regards,

Barry Thomas.
